awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Engineering Exceptional Points for Sound Control with Non-Hermitian Acoustic Metasurfaces
awd_abstract_narration:
This project focuses on creating a new class of non-Hermitian diffractive acoustic metasurfaces. Acoustic metasurfaces are thin artificial materials that can control sound waves. These two-dimensional materials are empowered with extraordinary control over the reflected and transmitted sound. This research will establish analogies between non-Hermitian quantum mechanics and acoustics, resulting in a paradigm shift in the design strategies for acoustic metasurfaces. The project will broadly advance the field of acoustic metasurfaces through discovering new mechanisms for designing materials with novel functionalities, which will have applications in noise control, architectural acoustics, and communication. The outcome of this research will also encourage future fundamental research where acoustics could serve as a platform to materialize quantum mechanics concepts. The research activities will involve undergraduate students, as well as students from under-represented groups, and will enable innovative educational activities. 

Non-Hermitian systems possess entirely real-valued energy spectra below a parity-time symmetry breaking threshold, which is referred to as its exceptional point. Here, the system undergoes a dramatic phase change with two or more eigenvalues and their corresponding eigenvectors coalescing. While physically this implies that the system would exhibit exotic wave functionalities, attaining an exceptional point requires the judicious tailoring of the system’s imaginary parts. The research team here, marries non-Hermitian physics with acoustic metasurfaces and seeks to develop fundamentally new designs that exploit the ubiquitous dissipation in the metasurface micro-structure. The project will examine the scattering matrices of non-Hermitian diffractive metasurfaces in order to establish frameworks that link exceptional points of a certain number and order to their corresponding scattering matrices. Methods for tailoring the loss in metasurface building blocks in a controllable manner will be theoretically investigated and mechanisms behind the overall diffraction behavior will be studied via classical acoustic theories. At last, the team will design, fabricate and experimentally demonstrate new acoustic devices that harness intrinsic losses, such as unidirectional sound diffusers. 
 

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The proposed project aims to pioneer new design paradigms that leverage loss in acoustic wave systems, advancing our understanding of acoustic metamaterials and offering fresh insights into non-Hermitian physics. By focusing on how quantum-inspired exceptional points, a key concept in modern non-Hermitian physics, can enhance the interaction between acoustic waves and artificial materials, we aim to bridge the gap between non-Hermitian quantum mechanics and acoustics. This innovative approach promises new strategies for managing and controlling sound, potentially revolutionizing the field of wave-functional materials.

In one study, we demonstrate that non-local acoustic metagratings, which enable precise and simultaneous control over multiple diffraction orders, can serve as a robust platform for investigating higher-order exceptional points in free space. This breakthrough provides a deeper understanding of wave interactions and offers a new method for exploring complex acoustic phenomena.

In another study, we designed, fabricated, and experimentally validated a type of lossy metasurface that selectively transmits acoustic waves based on the chirality of their orbital angular momentum. This metasurface, composed of a phase gradient metasurface and absorbing foam layers, significantly impacts sound transmission. Due to multiple internal reflections within the phase gradient metasurface and the carefully calibrated loss in the foam layers, left-handed incident acoustic vortices exhibit near-zero power transmission, while their right-handed counterparts show significant power transmission. This selective transmission capability opens new avenues for sound manipulation and control.

Finally, we conducted analytical and numerical studies on an ultra-sparse absorber array with a periodicity of 95% of the wavelength, achieving near-perfect (99%) sound absorption. Unlike previous works that relied on highly coupled resonances, our approach allows separate control of monopole and dipole resonators. This capability facilitates the simultaneous realization of degeneracy and critical coupling for perfect absorption, pushing the absorber array towards the theoretical limit for periodicity. We analyzed parameters such as eigenfrequency, leakage loss, and dissipation loss using finite element modeling. Comparing the analytical calculations of the absorption coefficient with numerical results, we found strong agreement, validating our design and approach.

Through these studies, our project seeks to create a paradigm shift in acoustic metamaterials and wave-functional materials, offering new tools and strategies for sound management and control. By harnessing the principles of non-Hermitian physics and exceptional points, this NSF award has unlocked new possibilities in acoustic technology, pushing the boundaries of what is possible in this vibrant and rapidly evolving field.
